Award.AwardTitle: BIGDATA: Collaborative Research: IA: Novel Bootstrap Procedures for Efficient Large Social Network Analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the structure and dynamics of social networks is crucial for detecting any anomalous behavior and for managing its impacts. Most existing approaches view a network as a series of snapshots, where a snapshot represents the state of a network in a given time period. Therefore, different network operations need to be individually performed over each snapshot. In reality, online social networks are continuously evolving and therefore, network operations should be automatically performed as networks evolve and need to be done efficiently and reliably. Viewing the problem from this perspective allows us to create a solution that supports advanced, real-world use cases such as tracking the neighborhood of a given node or tracking how network connections evolve in time to determine effective marketing campaigns. These examples indicate the need for efficient computing techniques for important network statistics as the large networks evolve over time. To address this problem, the researchers in this project complement existing distributed evolving social graph analysis techniques with bootstrap and other statistical re-sampling based approaches. The ultimate goal is to develop novel data-driven tools so that when needed, not only certain estimates of statistical network models could be computed efficiently but their estimation errors are reliably quantified.

This project primarily targets development of new efficient and robust methods for anomaly and outlier detection on large sparse networks. The resulting methodology provides the following functions: 1) a computationally efficient finite sample inference for an extensive range of network topology statistics; 2) a flexible data-driven characterization of network structure and dynamics, and 3) comprehensively quantifying uncertainty in modeling and estimation of large networks, without imposing restrictive conditions on network model specification. The expected advances are both in research methods - new approaches to data-driven nonparametric inference for large sparse networks and in substantial enhancement of knowledge of network dynamics and formation in the era of digital communication. The project can significantly benefit students by providing a broad exposure to interdisciplinary applications of large network and fostering awareness of interdisciplinary relationships -- hence enhancing their capacity for critical thinking and opening up new career paths.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project targeted development of data-driven methods for uncertainty quantification on large complex networks. In particular, the key goal has been to explore utility and limitations of various resampling procedures, such as bootstrap and subsampling on graphs, in conjunction with anomaly detection on large and possibly sparse random networks. Such nonparametric methods can be employed, for a example, for a more computationally efficient finite sample inference for an extensive range of network topology statistics, providing a flexible data-driven characterization of network structure and dynamics, and comprehensively quantifying uncertainty in random network modeling and estimation, without imposing restrictive conditions on network model specification.Throughout the course of the project, there have been developed new nonparametric approaches for resilience and vulnerability analysis of power grid networks, based on the idea of network motifs and topological representations of power systems; have been proposed new methods for e-crime detection on blockchain transaction graphs and elaborated new algorithms for anomaly detection in brain networks, while accounting for a broad range of the associated uncertainties. Furthermore, the project has resulted in introducing the notion of Levy flights for a more efficient exploration of large complex networks using graph neural networks, and developing a novel non-parametric bootstrap method for uncertainty analysis of node features in social network mining, along with deriving its asymptotic properties and demonstrating its effectiveness, with a particular focus on mental health applications.


 This project has offered a number of unique interdisciplinary research opportunities for students and postdoctoral fellows who have been involved into the undertaken activities. In particular, the mentees have actively participated in a broad range of collaborative research initiatives at the interface of computer science, statistics, computational mathematics, electrical engineering, neuroscience, and social sciences, often involving partners from industry and national research labs. Mentees have routinely spent their summers as research interns, acquiring core professional competencies outside academia. The project has involved 7 PhD students (4 of them are women) and 3 postdoctoral fellows, including Black and Hispanic mentees. The involved students have received 3 Best Paper Awards and multiple recognitions at national and international levels, and 5 of them proceeded to a research career in academia, while 2 are research scientists in industry. Furthermore, the results of the project have been incorporated into a new graduate course on statistical foundations of network analysis and integrated into the existing courses on cyber-security, machine learning, and data sciences. The algorithms developed throughout the project have beed implemented as a publicly available software in R and Scala/Spark. Finally, on the basis of this project, PIs have delivered multiple tutorials on blockchain data analytics and organized workshops on machine learning and statistical methods for emerging problems in blockchain graph analysis. 


Last Modified: 03/13/2021
Modified by: Yulia Gel
